user_idea: Propose the autoregressive image diffusion (AID) model for image sequence generation and apply it to sample the posterior for accelerated MRI reconstruction

final_story.title: Autoregressive Image Diffusion via Spatio-Temporal ODE Alignment for Zero-Shot MRI Reconstruction
final_story.abstract: We propose the Autoregressive Image Diffusion (AID) model to address the critical challenge of sampling high-fidelity posteriors in accelerated MRI reconstruction. Unlike existing methods that treat slices independently or rely purely on discrete sequential conditioning, we reframe this task as a Manifold Alignment challenge. Our approach aligns the generic visual manifold of pre-trained diffusion priors with the physical measurement manifold of k-space data through a unified dynamic system. We introduce a Spatio-Temporal ODE Alignment framework that treats anatomical sequence continuity as a geometric constraint, allowing the 'noise time' of diffusion and the 'spatial sequence' of MRI stacks to co-evolve. By implementing a Diffusion Exponential Integrator Sampler (DEIS) to solve this coupled system, we transform the reconstruction process into a high-precision numerical integration. This enables zero-shot volumetric reconstruction that maintains structural coherence and rigorous physical consistency without requiring sequence-specific training.
final_story.problem_framing: We reframe accelerated MRI reconstruction from a sequential slice generation task or a single inverse problem to a **manifold alignment challenge**. The core problem is bridging the gap between the semantic manifold of generic image priors and the constraint manifold of k-space measurements. This requires synchronizing the 'time' dimension of diffusion with the 'space' dimension of anatomical sequences under a unified dynamic system. We posit that the latent space of generic diffusion priors contains sufficient dynamic information to model anatomical continuity, allowing us to treat the pseudo-inverse sequence and the generic denoising trajectory as topologically isomorphic structures.
final_story.gap_pattern: Existing diffusion-based MRI methods fail to achieve this alignment because they treat inter-slice dependencies as discrete conditioning steps rather than continuous geometric constraints. Standard autoregressive models generate slices sequentially, ignoring the topological isomorphism between the pseudo-inverse trajectory and the generic denoising path. Furthermore, current approaches lack the rigorous numerical integration required to solve the coupled system of denoising and physical consistency. They struggle to balance the high fidelity needed for medical imaging with the speed required for clinical workflows, often sacrificing temporal coherence for fast individual sampling due to the prohibitive computational cost of sequential generation.
final_story.solution: We introduce **Manifold-Aligned Autoregressive Image Diffusion**, a framework that transforms MRI reconstruction into a Spatio-Temporal ODE Alignment process. By treating anatomical sequence continuity as a geometric constraint on the diffusion trajectory, we unify physical consistency and anatomical consistency into a single co-evolutionary manifold alignment process. We employ a modified score network parameterization that supports deterministic sampling across the sequence. Crucially, we utilize a Diffusion Exponential Integrator Sampler (DEIS) to solve the inter-slice coherence ODE concurrently with the diffusion denoising ODE. This technical choice transforms the slow, stochastic autoregressive generation into a fast, high-precision numerical integration, allowing us to sample the full posterior distribution of MRI sequences with significantly fewer function evaluations while maintaining structural coherence.
final_story.method_skeleton: Step 1: Formulate the reconstruction as a co-evolutionary system where the diffusion score function and the k-space measurement manifold are aligned via a unified Spatio-Temporal ODE, treating the slice index as a continuous variable in the generative process; Step 2: Implement a Diffusion Exponential Integrator Sampler (DEIS) to discretize this coupled ODE, leveraging the semilinear structure of diffusion processes to minimize discretization error in both denoising time and anatomical space; Step 3: Apply a quasi-Taylor scheme with ideal derivative substitution to approximate higher-order gradients of the manifold alignment, enabling efficient zero-shot posterior sampling without task-specific training.
innovation_claims: We transform autoregressive MRI generation from discrete slice-by-slice conditioning to **continuous manifold alignment**, bridging the generic visual prior and physical measurement manifold via a unified Spatio-Temporal ODE.

We transform the posterior sampling process into a **co-evolutionary state** by solving the inter-slice coherence ODE concurrently with the diffusion denoising ODE using a Diffusion Exponential Integrator Sampler (DEIS), eliminating the need for sequential generation loops.

We transform the requirement for task-specific training by positing **topological isomorphism** between generic priors and MRI trajectories, enabling zero-shot volumetric reconstruction through precise high-order numerical integration of the aligned manifold.
final_story.experiments_plan: We evaluate our method on the FastMRI and IXI knee/brain datasets to ensure generalizability beyond a single domain. Comparisons are made against state-of-the-art methods including standard autoregressive models (e.g., Video Diffusion Models), physics-informed diffusion models (e.g., CSDI), and unrolled optimization networks (e.g., VarNet). Metrics include PSNR, SSIM, and HFEN for image quality, along with temporal coherence metrics for sequence consistency. We conduct ablation studies on the ODE alignment term and the DEIS solver steps. Additionally, we provide a theoretical convergence analysis for the coupled Spatio-Temporal ODE system to address theoretical concerns.

reviews.feedback: Main gaps: Limited theoretical analysis without convergence guarantees, Restricted evaluation on single dataset with standard metrics, Lack of comparison with state-of-the-art MRI reconstruction methods. Anchored against 9 papers.

Main gaps: Limited theoretical analysis of the autoregressive approach for MRI reconstruction, Lack of comparison with other autoregressive models for medical imaging, Potential scalability issues for long sequences of MRI slices. Anchored against 9 papers.
Main gaps: Limited theoretical foundation, Insufficient experimental validation details, Unclear generalizability beyond MRI. Anchored against 9 papers.

final_top_k.name: Reframing Audio Understanding Through Multimodal and Probabilistic Learning

top_ideas.snippet: Utilize image diffusion models to address video inverse problems by treating the time dimension as a batch dimension and ensuring batch consistency.
Combine diffusion synchronization and score distillation sampling to enable zero-shot image generation in arbitrary spaces with weak conditioning.
Integrate autoregressive models with diffusion transformers to enhance long video generation by leveraging spatial and temporal information.
Reframe autoregressive sequence generation as an imitation learning problem to address compounding errors and improve sequence quality.
Leverage diffusion models for flexible and controlled human motion generation through novel composition methods.
Introduce a diffusion model that learns from a single motion sequence to synthesize diverse and realistic animations without additional training.
Integrate text and drag signals for precise and ambiguity-free image editing using diffusion models.
Enhance diffusion model diversity by annealing the conditioning signal during sampling to balance diversity and quality.
Improve diffusion model training efficiency and generation quality by aligning noisy input states with clean image representations from external encoders.
Introduce block diffusion models that combine the strengths of autoregressive and diffusion models to enable flexible-length generation and improved inference efficiency.
Extend diffusion models to pixel-level sketch generation with scale-adaptive guidance to balance recognizability and complexity.
Transform discrete diffusion model learning into a binary classification task to improve performance in language and image generation.
Enhance text-to-image generation by integrating retrieval mechanisms to improve image fidelity for rare entities.
Introduce discrete diffusion models to address the limitations of autoregressive models in complex reasoning and planning tasks.
Introduce a filtering-based approach to efficiently and accurately sample from the Bayesian posterior in diffusion models for linear inverse problems.
Integrate video generation and novel view synthesis into a unified diffusion model for consistent dynamic 3D content creation.
Introduce an autoregressive diffusion model for direct raw waveform generation, enabling high-fidelity and temporally coherent speech synthesis.
Introduce a unified model for scalable visual content generation across multiple modalities by leveraging a view-wise sampling algorithm and autoregressive generation.
Introduce Condition Contrastive Alignment to unify language and visual modalities in autoregressive visual generation, eliminating the need for guided sampling.
Introduce a unified diffusion model that combines blurring and noise to leverage both high-frequency and low-frequency image structures for improved generative performance.
